articles.headline: Immigration Crackdown With Firings, Not Raids
articles.snippet: The Obama administration wants to reduce illegal immigration by forcing employers to fire unauthorized workers. American Apparel fired 1,800 workers.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration wants to reduce illegal immigration by forcing employers to fire unauthorized workers. American Apparel fired 1,800 workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  A clothing maker with a vast garment factory in downtown Los Angeles is firing about 1,800 immigrant employees in the coming days  more than a quarter of its work force  after a federal investigation turned up irregularities in the identity documents the workers presented when they were hired.

articles.headline: Militant Network Is Intact Long After Mumbai Siege
articles.snippet: The group behind the assault in November 2008 has the capability and intent to strike India again, intelligence files show.
articles.abstract: The group behind the assault in November 2008 has the capability and intent to strike India again, intelligence files show.
articles.lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan  Ten months after the devastating attacks in Mumbai by Pakistan-based militants, the group behind the assault remains largely intact and determined to strike India again, according to current and former members of the group, Lashkar-e-Taiba, and intelligence officials.
articles.byline: By Lydia Polgreen and Souad Mekhennet

articles.headline: Rather’s CBS Suit Dismissed
articles.snippet: After the setback, the former anchor’s lawyer acknowledged that further pursuing the case could become significantly expensive.
articles.abstract: After the setback, the former anchor’s lawyer acknowledged that further pursuing the case could become significantly expensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dan Rather’s expensive attempt at vindication against his former employer CBS was repudiated Tuesday by the appellate division of New York State Supreme Court, which ruled unanimously to dismiss the $70 million lawsuit he had brought against the network in 2007.

articles.headline: How a Tax Can Cut Health Costs
articles.snippet: Lobbyists for unions and big business are staunchly opposed to a tax on generous health insurance plans, but their motives are questionable.
articles.abstract: Lobbyists for unions and big business are staunchly opposed to a tax on generous health insurance plans, but their motives are questionable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Slowing the growth of medical spending should, in principle, be one of the more popular parts of health reform. Health care already costs the typical household about $15,000 a year, and these costs are growing far more quickly than incomes. Yet when it comes time to turn principle into policy, the same problem always crops up.

articles.headline: Pickup Sales Fall in Another Blow to Automakers
articles.snippet: The closing of a big General Motors truck plant this week is another sign that America’s love affair with pickup trucks is fading fast.
articles.abstract: The closing of a big General Motors truck plant this week is another sign that America’s love affair with pickup trucks is fading fast.
articles.lead_paragraph: PONTIAC, Mich.  The closing of a big General Motors truck plant this week is another sign that America’s love affair with pickup trucks is fading fast.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Alternative Energy Projects Stumble on a Need for Water
articles.snippet: Many plans to meet the nation’s demand for power with renewable energy could consume billions of gallons of water every year.
articles.abstract: Many plans to meet the nation’s demand for power with renewable energy could consume billions of gallons of water every year.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMARGOSA VALLEY, Nev.  In a rural corner of Nevada reeling from the recession, a bit of salvation seemed to arrive last year. A German developer, Solar Millennium, announced plans to build two large solar farms here that would harness the sun to generate electricity, creating hundreds of jobs.

articles.headline: In Dispute With Iran, Path to Iraq Is in Spotlight
articles.snippet: While the similarities between 2002, when faulty intelligence estimates on Iraq were produced, and 2009 are unmistakable, the differences are profound.
articles.abstract: While the similarities between 2002, when faulty intelligence estimates on Iraq were produced, and 2009 are unmistakable, the differences are profound.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  To many Americans, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell’s February 2003 speech to the United Nations on Iraq’s unconventional weapons was powerfully persuasive. It was a dazzling performance, featuring satellite images and intercepts of Iraqi communications, delivered by one of the most trusted figures in public life.

articles.headline: Criticism Is Mounting Over Flood Premiums
articles.snippet: Congress is preparing to extend the National Flood Insurance Program, despite warnings that the program lacks adequate controls and may be shifting too much money to the insurance industry.
articles.abstract: Congress is preparing to extend the National Flood Insurance Program, despite warnings that the program lacks adequate controls and may be shifting too much money to the insurance industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Congress is preparing to extend the National Flood Insurance Program for another year, despite warnings that the program lacks adequate controls and may be shifting too much money to the insurance industry.
